titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Aust Papers OSB MSS 270
titlestmt.author: by Nora Soto

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Arthur Freeman on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Professional Papers, 1763-1827. II. Personal Papers, 1746-1837. III. Correspondence and Other Papers, 1762-1815. IV. Collection Inventories, undated.

bioghist.head: George Aust (1741-1829)
bioghist.p: George Aust was an English civil servant in the office of the Secretary of State in Great Britain during the reign of King George III. He was born in 1741 near Bath, England. After moving to London, he began his government career in 1763 as a clerk for the Northern Department of the Secretary of State, which would be reorganized as the Foreign Office in 1782. Aust was promoted to senior clerk in 1780 and appointed deputy writer of the official government journal London Gazette by 1781. In 1790, he was appointed Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, a position shared with Sir James Bland Burges, where Aust's responsibilities included the fiscal administration of the Secret Service under Lord William Wyndham Grenville, then Foreign Secretary. Upon retirement in 1796, Aust was appointed Commissary General of Musters and Secretary to the Trustees of Royal Hospital Chelsea, and later served as Secretary to the Westminster Hospital until 1826.

Aust was married three times and remained childless. Little is known about his first wife, who died in 1803. In November 1803, Aust married Sarah Murray (1744-1811), a topographical writer who published two travel books about Scotland. Sarah was previously married to William Murray, son of the third Earl of Dunmore, from 1783 until his death in 1786. Aust subsequently married Catherine Feaver in 1813. He lived in the West End and Chelsea districts of London, where he died in 1829.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George Aust Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: George Aust papers concerning the Secret Service, 1794-1800 (OSB MSS 148). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The George Aust Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The George Aust Papers consists of professional papers, legal and financial records, professional and personal correspondence, and other documents pertaining to the life and work of British civil servant George Aust. Aust's papers document his career of over fifty years in government service, including his position as Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs from 1790 to 1796. Correspondents include his wife Sarah Murray Aust; William Eden, first Baron Auckland; Sir James Bland Burges; Thomas Bowdler; Lord William Wyndam Grenville; William Augustus Miles; Lady Barbara Montagu; John Osborn; Bishop Thomas Percy; Sarah Scott; and Philip Yorke, second Earl of Hardwicke. The collection spans the years 1746-1837, with the bulk of the material dating from 1762-1827.

controlaccess.subject: Civil service -- Great Britain
Diplomacy
Government employees, English
controlaccess.corpname: Great Britain. Foreign Office -- Officials and employees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Professional Papers consists of documents related to Aust's civil service career in the Secretary of State for the Northern Department (which became the Foreign Office in 1782) from 1763 to 1796, particularly his appointment as Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, as well as later positions at the Commissary General of Musters office, Royal Hospital Chelsea, and the Westminster Hospital. Files include official documents, drafts, memoranda, lists, administrative records, financial records, salary negotiations, and professional correspondence concerning diplomatic work, foreign affairs, politics, the military, and veteran's pensions. Correspondents include diplomats, statesmen, and other government officials, such as Lord William Wyndham Grenville, then Foreign Secretary; Sir James Bland Burges; and William Eden, first Baron Auckland.

"The diamond snuffbox affair," as documented in the collection inventory in Series IV, refers to an incident during Aust's tenure as Under-Secretary of State, wherein fellow Under-Secretary Sir James Bland Burges received a cash gift and diamond-studded snuffbox in an exchange of diplomatic gifts with Russia, while Aust received nothing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological order, with files grouped by office held. Correspondence is filed at the end of the sequence.

did.unittitle: Secretary of State for the Northern Department and Foreign Office
"Titles of Foreign Princes as addressed by His Majesty," and "Forms of the Address and Superscription used by His Majesty in his Cachette Letters to the several Crowned Heads and Princes of Europe"
Letters from William Eden, first Baron Auckland, with letters from Francis Freeling, Lord Grenville, Viscount Bute, and Sir James Marriott
"The diamond snuffbox affair," concerning gifts from Catherine the Great to English diplomats, with letters from Sir James Bland Burges, and Louis Dutens
Commissary General of Musters, on account of fees and contingencies of the said office
Royal Hospital Chelsea, supplications by or on behalf of military men
Salary negotiations with the War Department, with letters from Lord Palmerston and Nicholas Vansittart
Letter from Morton Eden, first Baron Henley
Letter from John Waliot, with mention of Napoleon Bonaparte
Letter from George Aust to George Canning
Letters from Robert Jocelyn, Earl of Roden, and John Dalrymple, sixth Earl of Stair
Letters from Edward Stanley, and family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal Papers consists of records concerning Aust's roles as trustee and executor, personal financial records, and charity subscriptions. Materials include wills and related legal documents, account books, household expenses, subscriptions for newspapers and journals, bills, and receipts. The series also includes personal correspondence, and a small selection of Aust's literary writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by subject, reflecting the order found at time of acquisition.

did.unittitle: Unsorted correspondence, bills, and receipts, vellum
Letters from Robertson, William Philip Colyear
Letter from "Miss Dee" on behalf of Maria, Duchess of Gloucester
Lists of visitors to Staffa and Iona
Autograph manuscript verses for the birthday of Francis Osborne, fifth Duke of Leeds
Schedule to two houses, no. 7 and 8, Paradise Row, Chelsea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence and personal and professional papers of Sarah Murray Aust, George Aust's second wife, and others. Most of the correspondence is addressed to George Aust. Sarah Aust's papers consist of personal letters, financial records, legal records concerning her first husband William Murray, as well as drafts, publishing correspondence, and accounts with printers and booksellers related to her travel writing.

The series also contains letters from diplomat John Osborn, and a related collection of "Osborniana," including letters to Aust from Osborn's brother, Sir George Osborn, and Osborn's wills and estate documents. Additional correspondents are philanthropist and literary editor Thomas Bowdler; writers William Augustus Miles and Bishop Thomas Percy; philanthropist Lady Barbara Montagu; novelist Sarah Scott; and statesman Philip Yorke, second Earl of Hardwicke.

did.unittitle: Account book, executorship of William Murray's estate
Probate of the Will of the Honorable William Murray
Release of sums appointed by the will of the late Mrs. Aust
"A short descriptive arrangement of Gems, stones and spars, Earths metals and semi metals," autograph manuscript
Letters from Sir George Osborn, and Count Semyon Vorontsov [Woronzow], regarding the prisoner-of-war affair
Letters from Sir George Osborn, regarding message from John Osborn relating to Catherine the Great
Letters from Heneage Osborn, Thomas Metcalfe, and Mr. Luntly, financial agent, regarding Luntly's frauds
Letters from Sir George Osborn and other correspondents, regarding Patent Customers at Custom House, Cardiff
Draft will, Additional Codicils, and Minutes of the Will and Codicils of John Osborn Esquire
Yorke, Philip, second Earl of Hardwicke

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two inventories prepared for the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library contain detailed descriptions of the collection's materials, providing historical context and biographical information about Aust and his correspondents.
